VPA Baking Club invites you to bake these quick and easy brownies with your family this Memorial Day.

INGREDIENTS
3/4 cup vegetable oil
1 1/2 cups sugar
1 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
3 eggs
3/4 cup flour
1/3 cup + 2 1/2 tbsp cocoa
1/4 tsp + 1/8 tsp baking powder
1/4 tsp salt

INSTRUCTIONS
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Grease a 9√ó9 square baking pan, or line it with parchment paper.
2. Mix together the oil, sugar and vanilla extract.
3. Add eggs and mix until well combined.
4. Combine flour, cocoa, baking powder and salt.
5. Slowly add to the egg mixture until well combined.
6. Pour the batter into the pan and spread evenly.
7. Bake for 25-30 minutes, or until a toothpick comes out with a few crumbs.

Thank you Kole Zielinski, VPA Baking Club member for sharing this recipe from liveloveandsugar.com. Post pics and tag us #vpabakingclub #brownies #familiesbakingtogether

Sir Walter Scott 1771 ‚Äì 1832) was a Scottish historical novelist, poet, playwright, and historian. Many of his works remain classics of both English-language literature and of Scottish literature. ‚ÄúSoldier, Rest!‚Äù is the First Canto of Sir Walter Scott's poem ‚ÄúThe Lady of the Lake.‚Äù (which comprises six cantos). ‚ÄúThe Lady of the Lake‚Äù tells the story of Ellen Douglas and the conflict between the lowland and highland Scottish clans, as well as the conflict between the king (James Fitz-James) and the Douglas clan. Roderick Dhu leads the Highland clans against James Fitz-James, the king of Scotland. Meanwhile, Ellen Douglas is the lady of the lake (Loch Katrine in the Scottish Highlands).

Good morning, Veritas! Ms. Andaloro joins us today in Falcons Morning Announcements to recite a poem from Oliver Wendell Holmes. With its rich imagery and ringing verse, "The Chambered Nautilus," by Oliver Wendell Holmes, is one of the most enduring nature poems of the mid-nineteenth century. Its subject is the nautilus, a sea creature that lives inside a spiral shell. As it grows, the nautilus makes new, larger chambers of its shell in which to live, closing off the old chambers and gradually forming a spiral. Holmes compares the nautilus to a "ship of pearl" sailing through enchanted but dangerous waters until it is wrecked.

Ms. Andaloro encourage us that in these times that we find ourselves in, we can surely see the opportunity for growth in our own souls. You can watch the Falcons Morning Announcements in the VPA Remote Learning Site. post_text: Mr. Dick also joined us this morning in the Falcons Morning Announcements. Mr. Dick read a passage from Sir Winston Churchill‚Äôs essay ‚ÄúPainting as a Pastime.‚Äù Picking up a paintbrush for the first time at the age of forty, Winston Churchill found in painting a passion that was to remain his constant companion.
